title: Canyon launches all-new Grail, bids farewell to the double-decker bar
content:
Cyclist
Canyon launches all-new Grail, bids farewell to the double-decker bar

The new Canyon Grail drops the double deck bars of the original in favour of a more conventional-looking one-piece setup that Canyon calls Double Drop, which allow you to fit aero bars as well as a range of accessories.

There’s a new top tier CFR grade frameset, as well as CF SLX and CF SL frames. Canyon says that the CFR frame is 118g lighter and 10 percent stiffer than the CF SLX, while the fork is 4.5 percent stiffer.

The Grail’s geometry is now longer and slacker and tyre clearance is 42mm, which Canyon says allows enough space to fit a 52/36 double crankset, to satisfy the fast racers to whom the new Grail is geared.

Prices for the six Grail specs are from £2,599 to £7,649 with a run of 70 special edition Grail CFR Pro LTD bikes priced at £9,500.

More focussed race design

Back in 2018 when the original Grail was launched, gravel bikes usually did a bit of everything and the Grail V1.0 catered for that with 2× Shimano road bike gearing and its own custom bags for bikepackers. 

But Canyon points out that gravel has diverged into adventure-oriented and performance-oriented strands. The Canyon Grizl caters for the former while the new Grail 2.0 is more geared to gravel racing than the original Grail.

Canyon Grizl gravel bike review

What is a gravel bike? Everything you need to know

But no two gravel bike races are the same, Canyon says, with considerations such as tyre choice, feed strategy and even whether aero bars are permitted (they were banned for elite competitors at the 2023 Unbound gravel race). So it’s designed the new Grail to be customisable to fit the terrain and event.

Aerodynamics

The new bike has been ridden by Canyon’s pro gravel bike racers at a number of the big races this summer. It’s notched up a string of gravel race wins, including the women’s UCI gravel world championships under Kasia Niewiadoma.

Niewiadoma’s average speed over the 140km course was just shy of 30kmh and winning speeds in other races can be close to 40kmh. As on the road, at those speeds aerodynamics becomes increasingly important. So Canyon says that it’s designed the Grail to be aero, which is why it’s ditched the original Grail’s iconic double decker bars, as they increased the frontal area significantly.

Canyon says that it’s used the same tube shapes in the new bike as in its Ultimate road race bike. The original Grail’s split seatpost has been replaced by a D-shaped profile that is the same as the Ultimate, although with a carbon layup to add extra flex. 

It has added increased cable integration, again following the pattern of aero road bikes. You can add aero extensions from the Canyon Speedmax tri bike or, going against the usual wide bars for gravel bikes, spec narrow 400mm width bars, following a trend from pro road racers.

Canyon claims that, when compared to the original Grail in a wind-tunnel, the new bike is 9.1 watts faster at 45kmh for an identical spec.

Carry stuff to make you faster

There’s a new Aero Load System, which helps you to carry your gear but also, Canyon says, makes the Grail more aero. It’s made up of two parts.

The Load Down Tube Storage sits in the down tube cavity under a hatch and, much like the latest Canyon Endurace’s top tube storage, allows you to carry what you need for trailside repairs, including a multitool, tyre levers, CO2 inflator and TPU inner tube.

A second Load FidLock Quickloader bag uses three FidLock magnets to fix in place behind the head tube, so there are no straps required and it’s quick to add to the bike. Canyon says that the bag also works as a fairing (the UCI hasn’t got its hands on fairings on gravel bikes yet) and its wind tunnel testing shows that it makes the bike 1.5 watts faster.

New bar design lets you fit extensions

Canyon calls the new Grail’s bar design Double Drop. The one-piece bar/stem design includes a 5 degree backsweep and a downward sweep from the stem for a more comfortable riding position with elbows more tucked, and so more aero. The flare also increases from 5 degrees at the hoods to 16 degrees at the drops, which avoids the highly angled position that the levers can have on some flared bars.

There’s a long forward-facing section to the bars behind the hoods which has a slight recess, offering another hand position.

Another feature of the new cockpit is what Canyon calls the Gear Groove. This allows you to fit aero bars or a mount for a computer, camera, light or phone. Canyon will sell a range of accessories to fit, including adjustable aero extensions based on those of the Speedmax tri bike.

Canyon will offer the Double Drop bars in three specs, with CFR and SLX bikes getting the standard version, while you can spec a narrower 400mm width option designed for Canyon’s pro riders. A third design is fitted to Grail CF SL bikes and omits the Gear Groove accessory mount.

Canyon has replaced the VCLS split shaft seatpost of the previous Grail with a new D-shaped Comfortpost design that is similar to that in the Ultimate road bike, but with a different carbon layup to tune the flex for off-road riding. It claims that this is more aero, while some riders found the VCLS design too flexy for efficient power delivery. 

At 203g, the new seatpost saves 42 grams over the VCLS seatpost and riders can swap it out for the stiffer seatpost from the Ultimate, or a superlight 70g option.

Updated geometry

The new Canyon Grail will be available in a total of seven sizes from 2XS to 2XL. All roll on 700c wheels, unlike some of Canyon’s other bikes (including the original Grail) where smaller sizes are equipped with 650b wheels.

Trail83726969696767

All dimensions in mm unless stated

Canyon says that it assessed a range of geometries for the new Grail, using a test bike that could be quickly configured with different chainstay length, fork offset and head tube angle while out riding.

It says that the result of its tests is a geometry that differs from the first Grail to provide extra stability while still keeping the bike agile. Canyon says that this has been achieved via a one degree slacker head tube angle, which is now 71.5 degrees for frame sizes from S to L – not particularly slack by the standards of modern gravel bikes. There’s also a 27mm longer wheelbase, while Canyon has kept a consistent 69mm trail across the S to L frame sizes. 

Canyon claims that the new geometry results in neutral, balanced handling that increases confidence through fast turns and that rider weight is more evenly distributed for increased predictability and control on loose surfaces.

Surprisingly, Canyon has stuck at 42mm tyre clearance for the new bike, with all specs equipped with 40mm rubber. It says that this provides the clearance for a semi-compact 52/36 tooth crankset for racers wanting higher ratios than the usual gravel bike gearing allows. 

If you want wider tyres, it points you towards the Grizl, which has 50mm tyre clearance.

All the extras

Canyon hasn’t neglected practicality at the expense of speed, as you can fit mudguards with 42mm tyres and the usual top tube bag and third bottle cage. It also offers removable Load Fork Sleeves which allow you to carry up to 6kg of extra bottles or kit, while avoiding the reinforcement and hence additional weight needed for fork leg bosses.

New Canyon Grail specs and prices

The Grail frameset will be available in three grades of carbon fibre, including a new top spec CFR as well as CF SLX and CF SL. The Grail CF SL models don’t include down tube storage or the cockpit Gear Groove.

There are 70 special edition LTD bikes available at launch with a paint job that Canyon calls Grvl Dzzl, based on Razzle Dazzle camouflage which is designed to break up the outline of military vehicles to make them more difficult to target. They share the spec of the Grail CFR AXS and are priced at £9,500.
